Introduction

Trichomoniasis is a common sexually transmitted infection (STI) that affects both men and women and is caused by Trichomonas vaginalis, a motile, flagellated protozoan.  The majority of patients are asymptomatic, but trichomoniasis can cause vaginitis and cervicitis in women and urethritis in men.

Pathogenesis and risk factors



T vaginalis is a sexually transmitted flagellated protozoan that primarily infects the squamous epithelium of the urogenital tract (eg, vagina, urethra, cervix, prostate).  The adherence of T vaginalis to the epithelial cells causes direct cytotoxic cell damage and an inflammatory response, contributing to the symptoms of vaginitis in women and urethritis in men.



Risk factors for trichomoniasis include high-risk sexual behaviors (similar to other STIs) and include a history of other STIs, unprotected sexual intercourse, and multiple sexual partners.

Clinical presentation



Trichomoniasis is most often asymptomatic.  However, if symptoms are present, they differ slightly between men and women.

Women



Symptoms in women are due to cervicitis, vaginitis, and urethritis and may include:



  • Malodorous, frothy, greenish-yellow vaginal discharge (
    figure 1
    )
  • Vulvovaginal pruritus
  • Dysuria, urinary frequency (due to infection of the urethra)
  • Dyspareunia
  • Postcoital bleeding (due to capillary hemorrhages on the cervix and vagina [ie, "strawberry" cervix])

Men



Symptoms in men are due to urethritis and may include:



  • Clear-mucopurulent urethral discharge
  • Dysuria
  • Prostatitis, epididymitis (rare)

Diagnosis and laboratory evaluation



Nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) is the preferred method of diagnosis in both men and women due its high sensitivity and specificity.  Swab of vaginal fluid or first-void urine testing can detect the DNA or RNA of T vaginalis.



In women, the diagnosis can also be made via wet mount microscopy, which reveals motile, ovoid, flagellated organisms (

image 1
).  However, the sensitivity is lower (~50%-70%), so patients with a negative wet mount microscopy still require NAAT.  Occasionally, trichomoniasis may be diagnosed incidentally when protozoa are identified on Pap test cytology.



Routine screening is not generally recommended.  However, women with HIV should be screened for trichomonas infection when initially diagnosed with HIV and with each annual visit.  This is because even asymptomatic trichomonas infection increases HIV shedding, thereby increasing possible HIV transmission.

Imaging studies



Imaging is not typically performed in the diagnosis of trichomoniasis.  However, in cases where pelvic inflammatory disease is suspected, pelvic ultrasound may be indicated to assess for tubo-ovarian abscess.

Differential Diagnosis

Women



In women, the differential diagnosis includes other causes of vaginitis (

figure 2
) or cervicitis, including:



  • Bacterial vaginosis (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
    ):  Common noninflammatory cause of vaginal discharge characterized by a thin, gray, malodorous discharge.  Bacterial vaginosis has clue cells (
    image 2
    ) on microscopy and a positive whiff test (amine odor with KOH).
  • Vulvovaginal candidiasis (
    figure 3
    ):  Causes a thick, white, "cottage cheese-like" discharge and significant pruritus.  Wet mount microscopy shows budding yeast, pseudohyphae (
    image 3
    ), and hyphae.
  • Acute cervicitis from N gonorrhoeae and/or C trachomatis infection:  Can present with purulent discharge, postcoital bleeding, pelvic pain, or dysuria.  Diagnosis is confirmed most commonly by NAAT.


Other causes of vaginal discharge should be evaluated for if infectious causes are excluded.  These include atrophic vaginitis, retained foreign body, and desquamative inflammatory vaginitis.

Men



The differential diagnosis for trichomoniasis in men includes other causes of urethritis, such as:



  • Gonococcal urethritis:  Often presents with purulent urethral discharge, urethral inflammation, and dysuria.
  • Nongonococcal urethritis (eg, Chlamydia trachomatis, Mycoplasma genitalium):  Urethral inflammation, watery urethral discharge, and dysuria.


All forms of infectious urethritis are differentiated based on NAAT and can occur simultaneously.

Management



Treatment for trichomoniasis is required for the patient and all sexual partners, regardless of whether symptoms are present.  Treatment options include:

Women



  • Metronidazole:  500 mg orally twice daily for 7 days (a 2-gm single dose option is available but has a lower cure rate)
  • Tinidazole:  2 g orally in a single dose

Men



  • Metronidazole:  2 g orally in a single dose
  • Tinidazole:  2 g orally in a single dose


Sexual partners should also be treated to prevent reinfection.  Because rates of trichomoniasis are high when a sexual partner is infected, testing is not needed, and expedited partner treatment is appropriate (ie, providing treatment without testing).  Patients should abstain from sexual activity until they and all of their partners have completed treatment and no longer have symptoms.



Repeat testing should be performed for all women 3-12 weeks after treatment due to high rates of persistent infection and reinfection.  Repeat testing is not performed in men unless they remain symptomatic after treatment.



T vaginalis infection can increase rates of HIV transmission due to localized inflammation and impaired natural cellular defenses.  Therefore, it is important that after trichomoniasis is diagnosed, patients should be tested for HIV and other STIs.

Prognosis



With appropriate treatment, the prognosis for trichomoniasis is excellent.  Symptoms typically resolve quickly following antimicrobial therapy.  However, reinfection is common if sexual partners are not treated simultaneously.  Because trichomoniasis is frequently asymptomatic, the infection can be passed back and forth between sexual partners if they are not treated simultaneously or have multiple partners.  Untreated infection can lead to complications such as:



  • Increased susceptibility to HIV infection and other STIs
  • Adverse pregnancy outcomes
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease

Pregnancy considerations



When trichomoniasis occurs during pregnancy, there is an increased risk of complications, including preterm labor, prelabor rupture of membranes, and low infant birth weight.  However, the screening for trichomoniasis is limited to pregnant women at increased risk for STIs (eg, prior STI, multiple partners, HIV infection) or those presenting with symptoms.



First-line treatment in pregnancy is with metronidazole 500 mg orally twice daily for 7 days.  Although metronidazole does cross the placenta, there is low risk of teratogenicity.  Tinidazole is avoided in pregnancy due to limited safety data.



Repeat testing is performed after treatment to ensure reinfection has not occurred given the increased risks in pregnancy and importance of eliminating the infection before delivery.



Infants born to an infected mother may contract infection during a vaginal delivery.  Trichomoniasis infection in neonates may include respiratory distress, urinary tract infection, and vaginal discharge in female infants.

Prevention



Prevention strategies are largely focused on safe sexual practices, with consistent and correct condom use.  All sexually active individuals should be educated about the risks of unprotected sex and the importance of STI prevention.

Summary



Trichomonas vaginalis is a common and treatable sexually transmitted infection.  Most cases are asymptomatic; but can cause cervicitis or vaginitis in women and urethritis in men.  Both the patient and all their sexual partners require treatment to prevent reinfection.
